On Jan 25, 2007, at 11:23 PM, Shane Mingins wrote:

>
> What I have seen more is that these developers become "architects"
> whom design systems in such a manner that it makes it extremely
> difficult for the T1 developer to begin developer testing. The T1
> developer is not allowed to refactor the "architecture" to aid testing
> and so to implement testing is actually very hard work and you end up
> being the only one who cares. It's very frustrating.
>
> Cheers
> Shane
>
>


Shane,

I was in that situation once in the past. We said OK to the  
architecture, AND then we started building our part of the system  
driven by tests. As problems arose with the architecture, there was  
usually some really good OO design principle that could be used to  
explain the problem with the architecture. Sometimes that got the  
architecture changed; other times, we wrote our part of the system in  
an isolated, but testable manner and then wrote a bridge to connect  
it to the badly architected piece. This is not ideal, but being able  
to write your code effectively, and then adapt it to some other  
legacy system is often a better engineering decision, IMHO.
